questions.question: What is the definition of abnormal formation pressure?

options.B: Formation fluid pressure exceeding normal formation water hydrostatic pressure
options.D: Excess pressure due to annular pressure loss

questions.explanation: Abnormal pressure = formation pressure higher than normal hydrostatic gradient (0.433-0.465 psi/ft for water). This is what catches crews off guard.

questions.question: What are good top hole operating practices? (SELECT TWO)

options.B: Pump out of hole on trips
options.E: Keep mud viscosity high then pump fresh water pills

questions.explanation: Pumping out during trips maintains hole fill and reduces swab effect. Pilot holes detect shallow gas before full-size hole. High overbalance causes losses; rapid drilling increases swab risk.

questions.question: What factors increase swabbing risk? (SELECT THREE)

options.A: Pulling through tight hole with pump off

questions.explanation: Tight hole + no circulation + high pull speed + viscous mud = maximum swab. Pumping out (B, C) and slow pulling (F) REDUCE swab risk.

questions.question: What are good connection gas practices? (SELECT TWO)

options.D: Control ROP for single connection gas slug

questions.explanation: Short pump-off time reduces gas influx opportunity. Controlled ROP keeps gas slug manageable. Don't reduce MW or change viscosity—address the root cause.

questions.question: Observing rising cuttings volume, safe course of action?

options.B: Check for flow; circulate bottoms up at reduced rate

questions.explanation: Rising cuttings could indicate increased ROP or formation breakdown. Check for flow first (kick?), then circulate slowly to analyze cuttings without inducing losses.

questions.question: Action for total losses?

options.C: Fill annulus with water; record volume

questions.explanation: Total losses = no returns. Priority: Keep hole full to maintain hydrostatic. Use water (cheap, available) and record volume to track loss rate. Then address cause.

questions.question: Do kicks always follow total losses?

options.C: No, depends on mud level drop

questions.explanation: Kicks follow IF the fluid level drops enough to underbalance the formation. A kick-inducing zone must exist AND hydrostatic must drop to that level. Not automatic.

questions.question: When does gas in the wellbore reduce BHP?
questions.explanation: Gas expands as it rises due to decreasing pressure. At bottom, it's compressed and dense. Only at surface does expansion significantly reduce total hydrostatic column.

questions.question: What factors contribute to swabbing? (SELECT THREE)
questions.explanation: High viscosity increases drag. Balled BHA acts like piston. Fast pulling increases suction effect. Keeping hole full and pumping out REDUCE swab.

questions.question: What is swabbing?
questions.explanation: Swabbing = pulling pipe acts like piston, creating suction that reduces BHP. This can pull formation fluid into wellbore (swab kick).

questions.question: Heavy slug pumped, mud level drops in drillstring. Effect on BHP?
questions.explanation: Slug is HEAVIER than original mud. When level drops in DS, the heavier slug offsets lighter column above. Net BHP unchanged—that's the point of a slug!

questions.question: Swabbing suspected, flow check negative. Next step?

options.C: Run back to bottom; circulate bottoms up

questions.explanation: Negative flow check doesn't mean no swab occurred—gas may not have migrated yet. Run back to restore hydrostatic and circulate bottoms up to verify wellbore is clean.

questions.question: Effect of drilling through gas-bearing formation on BHP?
questions.explanation: Drilling gas causes small BHP reduction from gas-cut mud. Not a kick—just entrained gas from cuttings. Significant only if large gas volume enters rapidly.

questions.question: Light mud pill pumped. When does BHP decrease?
questions.explanation: BHP depends on TOTAL column weight. Lighter fluid entering annulus immediately reduces annular hydrostatic, therefore BHP. DS content doesn't directly affect BHP.

questions.question: Trip returns less than calculated indicate?
questions.explanation: Less return than displacement = mud went somewhere. Not total losses (would be zero returns). Partial losses to formation. Swabbing gives MORE returns, not less.

questions.question: Losing 20 bbl/hr into formation. Annular capacity 0.1252 bbl/ft, 12 ppg mud. BHP reduction after 2 hours?
questions.explanation: 40 bbl lost = 40/0.1252 = 319 ft of fluid level drop. Pressure = 319 × 12 × 0.052 = 199 psi ≈ 200 psi

questions.question: Why is pressure higher at top of trapped gas reservoir than gas/water contact?

options.A: Reservoir gas less dense than formation water

questions.explanation: Gas gradient (~0.1 psi/ft) much lower than water (~0.465 psi/ft). From contact upward, pressure drops less in gas than it would in water—so top of gas is overpressured relative to normal hydrostatic.

questions.question: Gas/water contact at 5,400 ft, top of gas at 4,000 ft. Gas gradient 0.1 psi/ft, water 0.465 psi/ft. Pressure at top of gas?
questions.explanation: Contact pressure = 5,400 × 0.465 = 2,511 psi. Gas column = 1,400 ft × 0.1 = 140 psi. Top pressure = 2,511 - 140 = 2,371 psi

questions.question: Gas cut mud zones: What is total BHP reduction? (Multiple density zones specified)
questions.explanation: Calculate each zone separately and sum the reductions from original mud weight hydrostatic.

questions.question: Pull 5 stands DC (90 ft each), DC cap 0.0073 bbl/ft, DC displacement 0.0370 bbl/ft. Fluid required?
questions.explanation: Total length = 450 ft. Displacement = 450 × 0.0370 = 16.65 bbl. This replaces the steel volume removed.

questions.question: 580 ft BHA pulled DRY. DC cap 0.0061 bbl/ft, displacement 0.032 bbl/ft. BHP reduction?
questions.explanation: Dry = air replacing mud. Loss = 580 × (0.032 + 0.0061) × mud gradient. Calculate hydrostatic loss from empty column.

questions.question: 10,100 ft depth. How many stands can be pulled dry before well flows?
questions.explanation: Calculate overbalance, convert to equivalent fluid column, divide by stand displacement.

questions.question: 10,000 ft, 7,000 ft shoe, 11.3 ppg mud, 600 psi surface pressure. BHP?
BHP while circulating with specified pressure losses?
questions.explanation: Static BHP + APL (annular pressure loss) = circulating BHP. APL adds to BHP during circulation.
